title: Jonah's Second Mission
shortSummary: In Jonah chapter 3, God commands Jonah a second time to go to Nineveh and preach repentance. Jonah obeys, and the people of Nineveh, from the king to the commoners, respond with fasting and repentance, leading God to relent from bringing destruction upon them.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - Jonah's prophetic mission to Nineveh

keyCharacters.name: Jonah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives God's command to preach repentance to Nineveh and obeys the second time.

keyCharacters.name: King of Nineveh
keyCharacters.description: The ruler of Nineveh who leads the city in repentance by humbling himself and decreeing a fast.

keyCharacters.name: People of Nineveh
keyCharacters.description: The inhabitants of the great city who respond to Jonah's message with fasting, sackcloth, and turning from evil.

definitions.definition: A coarse, rough fabric worn as a sign of mourning, repentance, or humility before God.
A voluntary abstaining from food (and sometimes drink) as an act of spiritual discipline and repentance.
A sincere turning away from sin and turning toward God, involving a change of heart and behavior.
To publicly announce or declare a message, often with authority and urgency.

outline.heading: God's Second Command to Jonah
outline.description: God commands Jonah again to go to Nineveh and preach; Jonah obeys and enters the great city, demonstrating God's mercy and the prophet's obedience.

outline.heading: Jonah's Warning to Nineveh
outline.description: Jonah proclaims God's message that Nineveh will be overthrown in forty days, calling the city to urgent repentance.

outline.heading: Nineveh's Repentance
outline.description: The people and king of Nineveh respond with fasting, sackcloth, and turning from evil, showing genuine repentance and humility before God.

outline.heading: God's Mercy Displayed
outline.description: God sees their repentance and relents from the planned destruction, highlighting His compassion and willingness to forgive.

application: Obey God's commands promptly, even if it requires going to difficult places or situations.
Recognize the power of genuine repentance to change hearts and avert judgment.
Lead by example in humility and prayer, just as the king of Nineveh did.
Trust in God's mercy and be encouraged that He responds to sincere turning from sin.

keyVerses.text: So Jonah arose, and went unto Nineveh, according to the word of the LORD. Now Nineveh was an exceeding great city of three days' journey.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Jonah's obedience and the vastness of Nineveh, emphasizing the scope of God's mercy.

keyVerses.text: So the people of Nineveh believed God, and proclaimed a fast, and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them even to the least of them.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the collective repentance of the city, demonstrating the power of faith and humility before God.

keyVerses.text: Who can tell if God will turn and repent, and turn away from his fierce anger, that we perish not?
keyVerses.significance: This verse expresses hope and faith in God's mercy, encouraging repentance with expectation of forgiveness.

keyVerses.text: And God saw their works, that they turned from their evil way; and God repented of the evil, that he had said that he would do unto them; and he did it not.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals God's responsive mercy and willingness to forgive those who genuinely repent.
